chinese_explanation:
以紀念 雅各・皮耶爾・貝爾特豪・范・貝爾克姆 (Jacob-Pierre Berthout van Berchem, 1763–1832) 而命名。他是一位定居瑞士的博物學家、礦物學家與地質學家，曾出版有關植物、動物與礦物的筆記，並活躍於洛桑的科學圈。
這個屬名常被誤認為源於他的父親 雅各・貝爾特豪・范・貝爾克姆 (Jacob Berthout van Berchem, 1736–1794)，一位富有的商人與奴隸貿易商，但他與植物學並無關聯。
德堪多爾 (De Candolle) 選擇此名，是為了紀念 雅各・皮耶爾 的科學貢獻。
english_explanation: Named in honor of Jacob-Pierre Berthout van Berchem (1763–1832), a Swiss-based naturalist, mineralogist, and geologist. He published notes on flora, fauna, and mineralogy and was active in Lausanne’s scientific circles. The name is often mistakenly linked to his father, Jacob Berthout van Berchem (1736–1794), a wealthy merchant and slave trader with no botanical ties. De Candolle chose the name to commemorate Jacob-Pierre’s scientific contributions.

chinese_explanation: 拉丁語 Genista，意為「金雀花」或「掃帚草」，指的是那些莖細長、如葦般的灌木植物，歷史上常用來製作掃帚或清掃工具。其詞源可能可追溯至拉丁語之前的伊比利亞語或凱爾特語根源（可比較古法語 genêt、西班牙語 retama、以及蓋爾語 beinnse）。
english_explanation: Latin: Genista — meaning “broom,” referring to the shrubby plants with slender, often rush-like stems used historically for sweeping or making brooms. Possibly connected to a pre-Latin (Iberian or Celtic) root (compare Old French genêt, Spanish retama, and Gaelic beinnse)

chinese_explanation:
(Diospyros lotus) — 指荷馬史詩中「食蓮族」（Lotus‑Eaters）神話裡的「蓮果」，象徵甜美與遺忘。林奈（Linnaeus）以此名指稱此種果實香甜、似棗的植物。

(Nymphaea lotus) — 源自希臘語 lōtos（λότος，「蓮」），反映其古老而神聖的地位，即「埃及蓮花」，這種純白的睡蓮沿尼羅河生長，在古埃及及古典文學中被奉為聖潔與再生的象徵。
english_explanation:
(Diospyros lotus) refers to the mythic “lotus fruit” of the Lotus‑Eaters in Homer — a symbol of sweetness and forgetfulness — and Linnaeus used it for this sweet, date‑like fruit.
(Nymphaea lotus) From Greek lōtos (“lotus”), reflecting its ancient sacred status as the “Egyptian lotus,” the pure water‑lily revered along the Nile and in classical literature.

chinese_explanation: 紀念 約翰・克勞狄斯・勞登 (John Claudius Loudon, 1783–1843)，著名的蘇格蘭植物學家、園藝學家與花園設計師，以其有影響力的著作及對植物學與園藝學的貢獻而聞名。
english_explanation: honoring John Claudius Loudon (1783–1843), a prominent Scottish botanist, horticulturist, and garden designer known for his influential writings and contributions to botany and horticulture.

chinese_explanation:
紀念 讓–巴蒂斯特·路易·克勞德·泰奧多爾·勒什諾·德·拉圖爾（Jean‑Baptiste Louis Claude Théodore Leschenault de La Tour, 1773–1826），法國植物學家與植物採集者，曾廣泛遊歷印度與東南亞。

其中詞根 Lud- 源自 Ludis-，屬於一種拉丁化的尊稱形式，乃由 Louis（路易） 演化而來，用以指代路易·勒什諾。
english_explanation: honors Jean-Baptiste Louis Claude Théodore Leschenault de La Tour (1773–1826), a French botanist and plant collector who traveled extensively in India and Southeast Asia. (Lud-: from Ludis-, a latinized honorific reference (derived from “Ludis-” → Louis, for Louis Leschenault).)

chinese_explanation: 來自希臘語前綴 ne‑（νη‑ 或 νέος‑），意為「非」或「新的、不同的」；以及 Kémias，該詞似源自 χῆμιον (chēmion)，古代詞彙學家用以指「蔓藤植物、攀緣草本或具鬚卷鬚的植物」。因此，Nekemias 可大致理解為「非真正的常春藤」或「與常春藤不同的新蔓藤」。
english_explanation: From Greek prefix ne- (νη‑ or νέος‑) meaning “not” or “new, different,”; plus and Kémias, apparently derived from χῆμιον (chēmion, an old or corrupt form sometimes used by ancient lexicographers to mean a vine, creeping plant, or tendril-bearing herb). Thus, Nekemias may be interpreted as roughly “not the true ivy” or “new vine distinct from ivy”

chinese_explanation: 源自希臘語 σχῆμα (schēma)，意為「形狀」或「外形」。此名稱可能由萊因瓦特（Reinwardt）所擬，並由布盧姆（Blume）正式採用，用以突顯這些山茶科常綠喬木在形態與結構上優雅而獨特的特徵。
english_explanation:
comes from the Greek σχῆμα (schēma), meaning “form” or “shape.”
It was probably chosen by Reinwardt (and validated by Blume) to emphasize the distinctive, elegant form and structure of these evergreen forest trees of the family Theaceae.

chinese_explanation: 紀念 安東・辛德勒 (Anton Schindler, 1879–1964)，德國植物學家，對中國與東亞植物研究有重大貢獻。
english_explanation: honoring Anton Schindler (1879–1964), a German botanist who contributed extensively to botanical research in China and East Asia.

chinese_explanation: 名稱源自 Silenus，希臘神話中酒神 Dionysus（狄俄倪索斯）那位開朗、嗜酒的隨從與導師。此名被認為暗指該植物莖部的黏性分泌物，讓人聯想起西勒諾斯滿身的汗滴或口邊的酒沫——這一象徵性的聯結自古以來即為人所提及。
english_explanation:
named from Silenus, the jovial, wine-loving companion of Dionysus in Greek mythology.
The name likely refers to the sticky exudate on the stems of these plants — reminiscent of Silenus’s sweat or the foam around his mouth — a traditional symbolic link noted since antiquity.

chinese_explanation: 源自希臘語 σμῖλαξ (smílax)，為古代對纏繞性、常具刺的攀援植物的名稱，同時也是希臘神話中一位被化為藤蔓的寧芙（山林仙女）之名。此名稱既反映了植物纏繞、攀附的生長習性，也象徵了自古以來人們賦予此類木質藤蔓的生命力與神話意涵。
english_explanation:
derives from Greek σμῖλαξ (smílax), an ancient name for climbing, sometimes prickly plants, and also the name of a nymph in Greek mythology who was turned into a vine.
The name reflects both the habit (twining, climbing) and the mythic vitality traditionally associated with these woody vines.

chinese_explanation: 源自 silva（樹林、森林）+ -ticus/-tica，形容「屬於、起源於」的特質。用於陰性名詞搭配，指「來自森林的」或「野生的」。
english_explanation: From silva (“forest, woodland”) + adjectival suffix -ticus/-tica, “belonging to, originating from.” Feminine form used with feminine nouns, often in botanical Latin.

chinese_explanation: 源自 silva + -ester/-estre，此後綴帶有「棲息於；與…相關」之意，多用於中性詞，表「森林性的、野地的」。
english_explanation: From silva + suffix -ester/-estre, denoting association or habitat. Neuter form meaning “forest-based, woodland,” used for plants or habitats.

chinese_explanation: 同樣源自 silva + -stris，是一種常見的形容詞化形式，特別在分類學中表示「棲於森林的、野生的」。
english_explanation: From silva + adjectival suffix -stris, widely used in Linnaean binomials, meaning “of the forest, woodland-dwelling, wild.”

chinese_explanation: 來自 希臘語 συμ- (sym-, “一起”) + φέρω (phero, “攜帶”) → symphoros（「一起承載、叢生」）+ καρπός (karpos, “果實”)，指「果實成群結聚」。
english_explanation: From Greek sym- ("together") + phoros (“bearing, carrying”) + karpos (“fruit”), meaning “fruit borne together/in clusters.”

chinese_explanation: 源自 συμφύω (symphyō, “一起生長、合生”) → symphyos（「合生的」）+ θρίξ (thrix, “毛髮”)；命名為「具毛狀結構，一起生成」。
english_explanation: From symphyos (“growing together”) + thrix (“hair”), referring to the tufted or hairy appearance of the florets.

chinese_explanation: 來自 συμφυτός (symphytos, “合生的、一起生長的”)；古人以其根部被認為具有「接合骨頭、治癒傷口」之效故得名。
english_explanation: From symphytos (“grown together, united”), alluding to its traditional medicinal property of helping bones knit/heal.

chinese_explanation: 「タデハギ」源自日語，因葉似蓼，花似萩，松村任三1902命名，後轉為屬名。
english_explanation: The name Tadehagi originates from Japanese, combining “tade” (Polygonum‑like leaves) and “hagi” (Lespedeza‑like flowers). It was first applied by botanist Ninzo Matsumura in 1902 to Desmodium pseudotriquetrum from Taiwan. Later, Hiroyoshi Ohashi adopted the Japanese name directly into Latin, establishing the genus Tadehagi in 1973.

chinese_explanation: 取自俗名 tali‑pariti。其中 “Pariti” 為一個通俗術語，廣泛用於指稱與木槿（Hibiscus）相似的植物，而前綴 “Tali‑” 則意為 「黏滑的、具黏液質的」。此種加詞（epithet）指向該樹 具黏液質的樹皮，其剝取的樹皮條曾 傳統上被婦女用作天然洗髮劑。
english_explanation: adopted from the vernacular tali‑pariti; a compound of “Pariti”, a vernacular term broadly applied to hibiscus‑like plants, and the prefix “Tali‑”, meaning slimy or mucilaginous. The epithet refers to the mucilaginous bark of the tree, the strips of which were traditionally used by women as a natural shampoo.
